Alpha is a measure of the active return on an investment, the performance of that investment compared with a suitable market index. An alpha of 1% means the investment's return on investment over a selected period of time was 1% better than the market during that same period; a negative alpha means the investment underperformed the market. Alpha, along with beta, is one of two key coefficients in the capital asset pricing model used in modern portfolio theory and is closely related to other important quantities such as standard deviation, R-squared and the Sharpe ratio. In modern financial markets, where index funds are widely available for purchase, alpha is commonly used to judge the performance of mutual funds and similar investments. As these funds include various fees normally expressed in percent terms, the fund has to maintain an alpha greater than its fees in order to provide positive gains compared with an index fund. Historically, the vast majority of traditional funds have had negative alphas, which has led to a flight of capital to index funds and non-traditional hedge funds. It is also possible to analyze a portfolio of investments and calculate a theoretical performance, most commonly using the capital asset pricing model (CAPM). Returns on that portfolio can be compared with the theoretical returns, in which case the measure is known as Jensen's alpha. This is useful for non-traditional or highly focused funds, where a single stock index might not be representative of the investment's holdings. == Definition in capital asset pricing model == The alpha coefficient ( α i {\displaystyle \alpha _{i}} ) is a parameter in the single-index model (SIM). It is the intercept of the security characteristic line (SCL), that is, the coefficient of the constant in a market model regression. S C L : R i , t − R f = α i + β i ( R M , t − R f ) + ε i , t {\displaystyle \mathrm {SCL} :R_{i,t}-R_{f}=\alpha _{i}+\beta _{i}\,(R_{M,t}-R_{f})+\varepsilon _{i,t}} where the following inputs are: R i {\displaystyle R_{i}} : the realized return (on the portfolio), R M {\displaystyle R_{M}} : the market return, R f {\displaystyle R_{f}} : the risk-free rate of return, and β i M {\displaystyle \beta _{iM}} : the beta of the portfolio. εi,t : the non-systematic or diversifiable, non-market or idiosyncratic risk It can be shown that in an efficient market, the expected value of the alpha coefficient is zero. Therefore, the alpha coefficient indicates how an investment has performed after accounting for the risk it involved: α i < 0 {\displaystyle \alpha _{i}<0} : the investment has earned too little for its risk (or, was too risky for the return) α i = 0 {\displaystyle \alpha _{i}=0} : the investment has earned a return adequate for the risk taken α i > 0 {\displaystyle \alpha _{i}>0} : the investment has a return in excess of the reward for the assumed risk For instance, although a return of 20% may appear good, the investment can still have a negative alpha if it's involved in an excessively risky position. In this context, because returns are being compared with the theoretical return of CAPM and not to a market index, it would be more accurate to use the term of Jensen's alpha. == Origin of the concept == Efficient market hypothesis (EMH) states that share prices reflect all information, therefore stocks always trade at their fair value on exchanges. This would mean consistent alpha generation (i.e. better performance than the market) is impossible, and proponents of EMH posit that investors would benefit from investing in a low-cost, passive portfolio. A belief in EMH spawned the creation of market capitalization weighted index funds, which seek to replicate the performance of investing in an entire market in the weights that each of the equity securities comprises in the overall market. The best examples for the US are the S&P 500 and the Wilshire 5000 which approximately represent the 500 most widely held equities and the largest 5000 securities respectively, accounting for approximately 80%+ and 99%+ of the total market capitalization of the US market as a whole. In fact, to many investors, this phenomenon created a new standard of performance that must be matched: an investment manager should not only avoid losing money for the client and should make a certain amount of money, but in fact should make more money than the passive strategy of investing in everything equally (since this strategy appeared to be statistically more likely to be successful than the strategy of any one investment manager). The name for the additional return above the expected return of the beta adjusted return of the market is called "Alpha". == Relation to beta == Besides an investment manager simply making more money than a passive strategy, there is another issue: although the strategy of investing in every stock appeared to perform better than 75 percent of investment managers (see index fund), the price of the stock market as a whole fluctuates up and down, and could be on a downward decline for many years before returning to its previous price. The passive strategy appeared to generate the market-beating return over periods of 10 years or more. This strategy may be risky for those who feel they might need to withdraw their money before a 10-year holding period, for example. Thus investment managers who employ a strategy that is less likely to lose money in a particular year are often chosen by those investors who feel that they might need to withdraw their money sooner. Investors can use both alpha and beta to judge a manager's performance. If the manager has had a high alpha, but also a high beta, investors might not find that acceptable, because of the chance they might have to withdraw their money when the investment is doing poorly. These concepts not only apply to investment managers, but to any kind of investment. == References == == Further reading == Bruce J. Feibel. Investment Performance Measurement. New York: Wiley, 2003. ISBN 0-471-26849-6 == External links == International Association of CPAs, Attorneys, and Management (IACAM) (Free Business Valuation E-Book Guidebook) The financial-dictionary entry on alpha Investopedia Alpha Definition Five Technical Risk Ratios Alpha analysis for global equities Free alpha look-up Traders Magazine Seeking Alpha - New York hedge fund creates value trading index options

items.question: What does an alpha of 1% signify for an investment's performance over a selected period?
items.answer: An alpha of 1% means the investment's return was 1% better than the market during that same period.

items.question: Why might an investor choose an investment manager employing a specific strategy over a passive one, despite the passive strategy's long-term performance?
items.answer: An investor might choose an investment manager over a passive strategy if they anticipate needing to withdraw their money in less than 10 years. A passive strategy's value can fluctuate and decline for many years, making it risky for short-term investors, whereas a manager might use a strategy less likely to lose money in a particular year.

items.question: According to the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH), why is consistent alpha generation considered impossible?
items.answer: The Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) posits that share prices reflect all available information, meaning stocks always trade at their fair value. Consequently, it would be impossible to consistently achieve alpha, which is defined as outperforming the market.

items.question: Explain the concept of alpha, its formal definition within the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM), and its practical application in evaluating investment portfolios.
items.answer: Alpha is a measure of an investment's active return compared to a suitable market index, where a positive alpha indicates outperformance. It is a key coefficient in the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). Within the CAPM, alpha is formally defined as the intercept of the Security Characteristic Line (SCL), representing the return that is not explained by the market's movements. This concept is practically applied as Jensen's alpha, which compares a portfolio's actual returns to the theoretical returns predicted by the CAPM. This is particularly useful for non-traditional or highly focused funds where a single stock index may not be a representative benchmark.

items.question: How did the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) influence the development of "Alpha" as a key performance metric for investors?
items.answer: The Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) posits that since share prices reflect all available information, it is impossible to consistently generate returns that outperform the market. This belief spurred the creation of passive investment strategies, such as market capitalization-weighted index funds. The success of these passive funds created a new performance standard, where investment managers were expected to generate returns exceeding this passive benchmark. Consequently, "Alpha" emerged as the term for this additional return achieved above the expected, risk-adjusted return of the market, signifying a return in excess of the reward for the assumed risk.

items.question: Why might an investor who anticipates needing to withdraw their money in the short term find a manager with both high alpha and high beta to be an unacceptable choice?
items.answer: An investor who may need to withdraw their money in less than ten years might find a manager with high alpha and high beta unacceptable. This is because a high beta signifies that the investment's value can fluctuate significantly, mirroring the risk of the overall market. For these investors, the chance they might have to withdraw their money when the investment is performing poorly due to this volatility outweighs the benefit of a high alpha.

items.question: Why has there been a historical shift of capital from traditional funds to index funds, based on the concept of alpha?
items.answer: Alpha measures an investment's performance compared to a market index. For a fund to provide better returns than an index fund, its alpha must be high enough to overcome its fees. Historically, the vast majority of traditional funds have demonstrated negative alphas, indicating they underperformed the market. This consistent underperformance has caused a flight of capital away from these traditional funds and towards index funds.

items.question: Explain the role of the alpha coefficient (αi) in the single-index model and how its value is interpreted in terms of investment performance.
items.answer: In the single-index model, the alpha coefficient (αi) is the intercept of the security characteristic line (SCL), as shown in the formula: SCL: R_i,t − R_f = α_i + β_i (R_M,t − R_f) + ε_i,t. The value of this coefficient indicates how an investment has performed after accounting for the risk it involved. A positive alpha (αi > 0) signifies that the investment has a return in excess of the reward for the assumed risk. An alpha of zero (αi = 0) means the investment has earned a return adequate for the risk taken. A negative alpha (αi < 0) indicates the investment has earned too little for its risk.

items.question: How did the Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) lead to the development of "Alpha" as a performance metric for investment managers?
items.answer: The Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH) posits that since share prices reflect all information, it is impossible to consistently generate returns better than the overall market. This belief spurred the creation of passive, low-cost index funds that replicate market performance. The success of these passive strategies created a new benchmark for investment managers, who were now expected to generate returns superior to this passive approach. The term "Alpha" was then coined to define this additional return achieved above the expected, beta-adjusted return of the market, effectively measuring a manager's ability to outperform the passive benchmark.

items.question: Why might an investor with a short-term investment horizon find a manager with both high alpha and high beta to be an unacceptable choice?
items.answer: Investors with a short-term horizon, who may need to withdraw their money before a 10-year period, often prioritize strategies that are less likely to lose money in a particular year. While a high alpha is desirable, a high beta indicates significant price fluctuation. This combination is risky for these investors because there is a chance they might need to withdraw their funds during a period when the investment is performing poorly due to its volatility, which they may find unacceptable.
